results.title: Aircraft at work
results.creator_credit: Donald Crosbie, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows various uses of air transport in Australian conditions, with some scenes of historic incidents in Australian aviation. Designed for use in schools.

results.title: Airborne
results.creator_credit: Chris Dillon, Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Explores the rugged inaccessible country where deer can be found. It contains thrilling sequences of low level flight over spectacularly beautiful unexplored terrain, and culminates in the excitement of a live deer capture.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Chris Dillon, Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit

results.title: Air!
results.creator_credit: Paul Driessen, Pierre Moretti and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: This animated short makes the point that oxygen is the stuff of life whether on land, in the air or water, but that it is becoming scarcer as man-made pollutants crowd it out. It is a film without words in which plants, birds, fish and, finally, man come to the same ‘breathless’ end. (Awards: San Francisco, Belgrade)

results.title: Air power is peace power
results.brief_description: Short documentary featuring WWI American ace air pilot, Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker (President of Eastern Air Lines), representing the airline’s push for more air power in the United States in the form of the Constellation airplane.

results.title: Air pollution: a first film
results.creator_credit: Norman Bean and Norman Bean Films
results.brief_description: This film explains that almost all of man’s activities can contribute to air pollution. It outlines the problems associated with air pollution and indicates that everyone must share in correcting pollution problems. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Air pollution
results.creator_credit: Journal Films and Gilbert Altschul Productions
results.brief_description: Defines air pollution and views the many man-made and natural causes. Uses plant life to show how pollution affects health and the economy. Discusses elimination of the sources of pollution and possible methods of control. Covers facts and broad social trends relating to the problem.

results.title: Air parade: a Shell film for the Festival of Britain 1951
results.creator_credit: Bill Mason and Shell Film Unit
results.brief_description: A brief history of aviation in Britain commencing with Bleriot’s crossing of the Channel in 1909 and ending with the development of the gas-turbine airliner. This film traces the development of both military and civil aircraft including the Viscount turbo-jet and the Comet.

results.title: Air links of the world. No. 6. Southern Cross route
results.creator_credit: Lex Halliday, Jean Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description: Shows the air route between Australia and America pioneered by Kingsford-Smith in the Southern Cross. An Australian family flies from Australia to the USA. Maps and scenes of route and places visited including Fiji, Canton Island, Hawaii to San Francisco.

results.title: Air Force One
results.creator_credit: Wolfgang Petersen, Jonathan Shestack, Gail Katz, Armyan Bernstein and Buena Vista International
results.brief_description: Cementing his status as action hero leading man, Harrison Ford plays the United States President who also happens to be a Vietnam War hero. Trapped aboard his private jet, President Marshall must display a steely reserve in the face of unhinged kidnappers. Peterson (In the Line of Fire, The Perfect Storm, Troy) ably directs this mainstream thriller that produces a tangle of twists but lacks the enormous tension generated by his classic wartime nail-biter “Das Boot”. Cast also includes Gary Oldman, Wendy Crewson, Paul Guilfoyle, Glenn Close, Dean Stockwell, William H. Macy.

results.title: Air crossroads - London
results.creator_credit: John Arnold, Film Workshop, Central Office of Information and Basic Films
results.brief_description: London is the busiest airport in the world; 38 airlines use it and some 600 planes arrive and depart every 24 hours. Passengers from many nations pass through the airport and are assisted in every way posible by an efficient staff. The control tower and servicing staff are in operation seven days of the week, 24 hours a day. When passenger planes are not so numerous heavy freight planes take over. Radio control enables planes to land and take off in foggy weather and at night.
